hawaiian_text: A lohe 'o 'Ama'u, ho'omākaukau ihola ia i kona mau wa'a kaua he 'umi kumamāwalu, a holo akula i lalo o 'Ewa e kaua me Nāmakaokapāo'o. A hiki 'o 'Ama'u me kona po'e kānaka ma 'Ewa, e noke mai ana 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o i ka luku ā pau loa, 'a'ohe kanaka koe, a make ihola 'o 'Ama'u. Puni a'ela 'o O'ahu nei iā Nāmakaokapāo'o, a laila, ki'i akula ia i kona makuahine a ho'onoho ihola i luna o ka 'āina O'ahu nei.
llama-3.3-70B-Instruct_exl2_6.0bpw-maui_: Ama'u listened and prepared his eighteen war canoes and sailed to 'Ewa to battle Nāmakaokapāo'o. When Ama'u and his men arrived at 'Ewa, Nāmakaokapāo'o charged forward, alone and unaccompanied, and Ama'u was killed. The island of O'ahu was conquered by Nāmakaokapāo'o, and then he visited his mother and was installed as the ruler of the land of O'ahu.

**Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>Ama'u listened and prepared his eighteen war canoes and sailed to 'Ewa to battle Nāmakaokapāo'o. When Ama'u and his men arrived at 'Ewa, Nāmakaokapāo'o charged forward, alone and unaccompanied, and Ama'u was killed. The island of O'ahu was conquered by Nāmakaokapāo'o, and then he visited his mother and was installed as the ruler of the land of O'ahu.</translation>

<commentary>This paragraph marks a pivotal moment in the narrative, as Nāmakaokapāo'o faces off against Ama'u in battle, resulting in the conquest of O'ahu and Nāmakaokapāo'o's ascension to power.</commentary>

• The narrative begins with 'A-ma'u (the pit of the breadfruit), a character introduced as a rival to Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o, listening and preparing for battle. 
– The use of the name 'A-ma'u is significant, as it references the breadfruit (ma'u), a staple crop in ancient Hawaiian society. 
– The fact that 'A-ma'u prepares eighteen war canoes (he 'umi kumamāwalu) suggests a substantial military force, emphasizing the importance of this battle.
• The battle takes place in 'E-wa (the red or inflamed area), a location on the island of O'ahu. 
– Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o is described as charging forward alone (i ka luku ā pau loa), without any companions or support, highlighting his exceptional strength and bravery.
– The outcome of the battle is decisive, with 'A-ma'u being killed (make ihola) by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o.
• The consequences of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's victory are far-reaching, as he conquers the island of O'ahu (Puni a'ela 'o O'ahu nei) and establishes himself as its ruler. 
– The fact that Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o visits his mother (ki'i akula ia i kona makuahine) after his victory suggests a desire to reconnect with his family and cultural heritage.
– The installation of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o as the ruler of O'ahu (ho'onoho ihola i luna o ka 'āina O'ahu nei) marks a significant turning point in the narrative, as he assumes a position of power and authority.
• The allegorical significance of this passage can be interpreted in the context of Hawaiian cultural tradition. 
– Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's conquest of O'ahu may represent the triumph of progressive thinking and the abandonment of outdated 'Ai Kapu customs.
– The character of 'A-ma'u, with his association with the breadfruit, may symbolize the old ways and traditions that are being supplanted by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's new order.
– The number eighteen, referenced in the preparation of the war canoes, may hold symbolic significance, potentially representing the eighteen major islands of the Hawaiian archipelago or the eighteen principal gods of the Hawaiian pantheon. 
– Further research and analysis are needed to fully understand the cultural and historical context of this passage and its significance within the broader narrative.
reference_translation: When 'Ama'u heard about it, he prepared eighteen of his war canoes and went over to 'Ewa to make war with Nāmakaokapāo'o. When 'Ama'u reached 'Ewa with his men, Nāmakaokapāo'o went to work killing them all sparing no one, and that is how 'Ama'u died. All of O'ahu fell to Nāmakaokapāo'o. Then he went and got his mother and set her up as ruler over all of O'ahu.
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
